summary:
For a pair of positive integers (k,r) with r>1 such that k+1 and r-1 are
relatively prime, we describe the space of symmetric polynomials in variables
x_1,...,x_n which vanish at all diagonals of codimension k of the form
x_i=tq^{s_i}x_{i-1}, i=2,...,k+1, where t and q are primitive roots of unity of
orders k+1 and r-1.

SYMMETRIC POLYNOMIALS VANISHING ON THE DIAGONALS
SHIFTED BY ROOTS OF UNITY.
B. FEIGIN, M. JIMBO, T. MIWA, E. MUKHIN AND Y. TAKEYAMA
Abstract. For a pair of positive integers (k, r) with r ≥ 2 such that k + 1 and r − 1
are relatively prime, we describe the space of symmetric polynomials in variables
x1 , . . . , xn which vanish at all diagonals of codimension k of the form xi = tq si xi−1 ,
i = 2, . . . , k + 1, where t and q are primitive roots of unity of orders k + 1 and r − 1.

0 on all planes which have the form
x2 = t1 x1 , x3 = t2 x2 , . . . , xl = tl−1 xl−1 , x1 = tl xl ,

A partition λ ∈ πn is called (k, r, n)-admissible if λi − λi+k ≥ r for i = 1, . . . , n − k.
We will use (k, 1, n)-admissibility in this paper. This is equivalent to the condition
that mi (λ) ≤ k for all i. In the below we simply call λ is (non)-admissible with the
understanding that it means the (non)-admissibility for (k, 1, n) with a prescribed value
of k.
There is a partial dominance order of partitions. For two partitions λ, μ of the same
weight we write λ > μ iff λ 6= μ, λ1 + * * * + λi ≥ μ1 + * * * + μi for all i.
We also use the total lexicographical order of partitions. For two partitions λ, μ of the
same weight we write λ ≺ μ iff for some i we have λi < μi and λj = μj , j = 1, . . . , i − 1.

Proposition 3.5. The set of Hall-Littlewood polynomials {Pλ (x1 , . . . , xn ; t)}, where λ

Proof. The admissibility of λ is nothing but mi (λ) ≤ k. It implies that polynomials

definition that they satisfy the condition (6), since every term in (4) satisfies it.
On the other hand, by Lemma 3.3, the dimension of the space of polynomials in

4.2. Slim partitions. We describe the division with remainders of partition by positive integers.
By definition, the result of addition of two partitions λ, μ ∈ πn is a partition (λ+μ) ∈
πn with components λi + μi , i = 1, . . . , n. In particular, the result of multiplication
of a partition λ by a positive integer r − 1 is the partition (r − 1)λ with components
(r − 1)λi . A partition λ is called divisible by a positive integer r − 1 if all parts λi are
divisible by r − 1.
Let a symmetric polynomial f (x1 , . . . , xn ) be expressed in terms of monomial funcP
tions f = λ cλ mλ , cλ ∈ C. Then f (x1 , . . . , xn ) = f ̃(x1r−1 , . . . , xnr−1 ) for some symmetric polynomial f ̃ if and only if cλ = 0 for all λ which are not divisible by r − 1.
A partition λ ∈ πn is called (r − 1)-slim if λi − λi+1 < r − 1 for i = 1, . . . , n − 1 and
λn < r − 1. We denote the subset of πn consisting of all (r − 1)-slim partitions by πns .
The cardinality of πns is N = (r − 1)n .
The following lemma is straightforward.
Lemma 4.2. Let λ ∈ πn . There is a unique way to represent λ in the form
λ = (r − 1)μ + ν,
where μ, ν ∈ πn are partitions and ν is (r − 1)-slim. 
The partitions μ, ν in the lemma are called the quotient and the remainder of partition
λ divided by integer r − 1.
